column8: J.|European Planetary Science Congress 2008|||331|Introduction Several thousand seismic events were recorded by the Apollo seismic network from 19691977. Different types of events can be distinguished: meteoroid impacts
column9: thermal quakes and internally caused moonquakes. The latter subdivide into shallow (100 to 300km) and deep moonquakes (700 to 1100km)
column10: which are by far the most common events. The deep quakes would be no immediate danger to inhabitated stations on the Earth's Moon because of their relatively low magnitude and great depth. However
column11: they bear important information on lunar structure and evolution
column12: and their distribution probably reflects their source mechanism. In this study
column13: we reinvestigate location patterns of deep lunar quakes. LOCSMITH The core of this study is a new location method (LOCSMITH
column14: [1]). This algorithm uses time intervals rather than time instants as input
column15: which contain the dedicated arrival with probability 1. LOCSMITH models and compares theoretical and actual travel times on a global scale and uses an adaptive grid to search source locations compatible with all observations. The output is a set of all possible hypocenters for the considered region of repeating
column17: called clusters. The shape and size of these sets gives a better estimate of the location uncertainty than the formal standard deviations returned by classical methods. This is used for grading of deep moonquake clusters according to the currently available data quality. Classification of deep moonquakes As first step
column18: we establish a reciprocal dependence of size and shape of LOCSMITH location clouds on number of arrivals. Four different shapes are recognized
column19: listed here in an order corresponding to decreasing spatial resolution: 1. "Balls"
column20: which are well defined and relatively small types of sets resembling the commonly assumed error ellipsoid. These are found in the best cases with many observations. Locations in this shape are obtained for clusters 1
column22: these were already well located by earlier works [2
column23: 3]. 2. The next best shape of a location set is the "banana" as found for clusters 5
column25: only limited depth resolution is available
column26: and the solution spreads over a large volume. The size of a "banana" could be minimized by either finding a not yet discovered shear wave arrival or estimating a S arrival time interval by considering the coda instead of a clear S arrival. 3. Shape of clouds we call "cones" are formed by clusters for which no compressional wave arrivals
column27: but three S arrivals were picked. Such solutions were found for clusters 35
column28: 201 or 218 [Fig. 2]. A depth limitation is given only by the surface of the Moon's far side. In previous works
column29: locations of these clusters were usually determined with a fixed depth
column30: thus neglecting all depth uncertainty [2]. 4. The fourth and worst class shows a "disc"like shape with no depth resolution and almost no latitude resolution. Clusters of this class
column33: were not located so far. From class 1 ("ball") to 4 ("disc") the amount of possible hypocenters increases. So we also found a correlation between size and shape of volumes containing possible hypocenter solutions. Aim We classified all clusters according to the solution set scheme by using arrival times of [2] with an estimated error of ±10s as input for LOCSMITH. We reprocess selected clusters of each class to come up with the special requirements and possibilities of this new location method. As said above
column34: one of the requirements of LOCSMITH is the definition of a time interval instead of a time instant for input
column35: and an interesting option is using an estimated S arrival time interval derived from coda and scattering model
column36: lacking a clear S arrival. We try to find fully automated methods for each processing step
column37: dependent on the quality of data. Methods For despiking we merged methods by [4] and [5] and achieve very good results even for worst case as already presented in [6]. Prior to stacking we developed a complex multiparameter correlation algorithm to calculate the optimum time shift. Results We present relocations of selected deep moonquakes in context of data availability and quality. Previous locations are often contained in our location clouds
column38: but realistic location uncertainties allow large deviations from the best fitting solutions
column39: including locations on the far side of the Moon. Perspective By developing new methods for data processing and using the LOCSMITH locating algorithm we hope to reduce the location uncertainty sufficiently to make sure that all sources are on the near side
column40: or to prove a far side origin of some of them. This would answer questions of hemispheric symmetry of lunar deep seismicity and the Moon's internal structure. References [1] Knapmeyer (2008) accepted to GJI. [2] Nakamura (2005) JGR

column1: 1984LPSC...15..171E|1984|Cosmic ray exposure histories and U-235-Xe-136 dating of Apollo 11
column12: H.|Lunar and Planetary Science Conference Proceedings|89||C171|The history of exposure to cosmic rays was studied for nine basaltic rocks based on the cosmic-ray-produced noble gas isotopes. The results for the five basalts 10003
column16: and 77135 are consistent with a single-stage exposure. Four basalts
column21: experienced a multistage exposure. Using the U-235-Xe-136 dating method
column22: the time of their early exposure to cosmic rays on the lunar surface was dated to have begun three to four aeons ago
column23: immediately after rock formation as defined by their crystallization ages. The durations and shielding depths for the proposed two-stage exposure models of the four basalts were calculated. From the shielding at the early stage
column24: a lower limit of 50 cm is estimated for the thickness of the lava flows from which the investigated basalts originate.|http://dx.doi.org/10.1029/JB089iS01p0C171

column4: D. P.|Lunar and Planetary Science Conference Proceedings|1||49|A reexamination of the bulk major and trace element geochemistry of Apollo 11 low-K mare basalts is presented. New analyses are given for seven previously unanalyzed samples (10003
column10: and 10062) and for two low-K basalts (10029 and 10092) and one high-K basalt (10071) for which comprehensive compositional data were previously lacking. The data show that three distinct magma types have been sampled
column11: as proposed by Beaty and Albee (1978)
column12: and that these magma types are unrelated by near-surface crystal fractionation. Each magma type is characterized by distinctive magmaphile element ratios
column13: which enable previously unclassified samples (10050 and 10062) to be assigned to an appropriate magma type.|

column1: 1979LPSC...10....1G|1979|Classification of the Apollo-11 mare basalts according to Ar<SUP>39</SUP>-Ar<SUP>40</SUP> ages and petrological properties.|Guggisberg
column14: A.|Lunar and Planetary Science Conference Proceedings|1||1|Previously unpublished (Ar-39)-(Ar-40) ages and exposure ages are presented for Apollo 11 whole rocks and mineral separates. The age data for the Apollo 11 mare basalts in general are discussed in relation to their textural and petrological properties. The oldest rocks (10003
column15: 10029) belong to the low-K group and crystallized at 3.90 + or - 0.03 AE. Three other low-K groups are defined in relation to the petrological classification of Beaty and Albee (1978) and to information on the rock crystallization ages
column16: exposure ages and normative quartz contents. These groups have ages of 3.84 + or - 0.04 AE (10062)
column19: 10058). The best defined (Ar-39)-(Ar-40) age for the high-K basalts is 3.62 + or - 0.05 AE (for mineral separates from 10072). At least four distinct
column20: fairly thin flows of low-K basalt are believed to have been erupted over a 200-my period
column21: followed by either one or several
column23: very thin flows of high-K basalt. It is not possible to decide whether the earliest dated of the mare basalt eruptions at Mare Tranquillitatis pre-dated
column25: or were contemporary with the Imbrian impact event.|

column1: 1978LPSC....9..495G|1978|The consanguinity of the oldest Apollo 11 mare basalts.|Gamble
column6: L. A.|Lunar and Planetary Science Conference Proceedings|1||495|The textural
column8: and chemical relationships between three of the oldest dates lunar mare basalt samples returned by Apollo 11 (10003
column9: 10029 and 10062) were investigated. Very strong resemblances were noted between the modal minerologies of 10003 and 10029. Significantly more modal olivine and cristobalite was observed in 10062 than in the other basalt samples. A detailed examination of mineral-chemical relationships among the samples revealed similarities between 10003 and 10062 and differences between these two rocks and 10029
column10: the most significant of which is the presence of akaganeite in 10029
column11: implying that lawrencite was present in the pristine sample of 10029 but not in 10003 and 10062. Results of a Wright-Doherty mixing program used to test various fractional crystallization schemes show that 10062 can be derived from a liquid with the composition of either 10003 or 10029 by removing 2-5% ilmenite and 5% olivine. By removing about 6% plagioclase
column12: 10003 can be derived from a liquid with the bulk composition of 10062. It is concluded that 10003 and 10029 may have come from different basaltic flows
column13: whereas it is possible that 10003 and 10062 were derived from the same parental magma by near-surface fractionation of olivine plus ilmenite or of plagioclase plus or minus olivine.|

column1: 1977RSPTA.285..151G|1977|Absolute Time Scale of Lunar Mare Formation and Filling|Geiss
column12: A.|Philosophical Transactions of the Royal Society of London Series A|285|1327|151|The high titanium basalts collected in the maria Tranquillitatis and Serenitatis crystallized 3.5-3.9 Ga ago. The ages of the low titanium rocks found in Oceanus Procellarum and on the eastern edge of mare Imbrium are lower
column15: evidence that high-Ti basalts with lower ages and low-Ti basalts with higher ages occur on the Moon. The observed age spread of rocks even in limited areas suggests that lava flow activity in a basin lasted for several 100 Ma. The age variability of Apollo 11 basalts is particularly well documented: there are at least three different times of rock formation
column16: two for the low-K and one for the high-K rocks. The ages of the oldest mare basalts 10003 (high-Ti
column17: low-K rock) and 14053 (an igneous rock with low-Ti
column19: high-Al mare basalt composition) of 3.91 ± 0.03 Ga and 3.95 ± 0.03 Ga respectively
column20: suggest that mafic basalt flows had already begun to invade the older basins when the last basin-forming impacts occurred.|http://dx.doi.org/10.1098/rsta.1977.0051

column12: A.|Earth and Planetary Science Letters|11|1|245|The K-Ar ages of a whole rock sample and a feldspar concentrate from lunar rock 10003 were determined as (3.74 ± 0.06) × 10 <SUP>9</SUP>y and (3.82 ± 0.05) × 10 <SUP>9</SUP>y respectively. The K sbnd Ar age of the feldspar concentrate is in essential agreement with the high temperature K sbnd Ar age of (3.92 ± 0.07) × 10 <SUP>9</SUP>y obtained by Turner [1] with the <SUP>40</SUP>Ar/ <SUP>39</SUP>Ar dating technique. Our results thus confirm the relatively high age of the low-K Apollo 11 rock 10003.|http://dx.doi.org/10.1016/0012-821X(71)90171-3

column14: optical and electron optical examinations of clinopyroxenes from Apollo 11 lunar samples 10003
column17: and 10084 show that generally the crystals are composed of (001) augite-pigeonite intergrowths in varying ratios. Transmission electron micrographs reveal abundant exsolution lamellae
column18: many only 60 Å thick. In addition to the phase inhomogeneities
column19: primary chemical inhomogeneities are clearly demonstrated. There are reciprocal relationships between calcium and iron and between Ti<SUP>4+</SUP> + 2Al and R<SUP>2+</SUP> + 2Si. Our evidence suggests that a chemically inhomogeneous subcalcic C2/c augite was the only primary pyroxene from which pigeonite later exsolved.|http://dx.doi.org/10.1126/science.167.3918.628
